body:
> there's no 1:1 mapping between suite chunk on a platform and suite chunk on another platform (chunking can be different).

If this wasn't the case, we could have trained the model using just the suite chunk names rather than the full job name.

issue.title: Add past failures in suite features

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
Right now, we are considering past failures with the task in the past. It might be worth considering past failures in the suite in the past (to mitigate the fact that chunks are not always the same).

See also #1117.

body: This problem would be solved if we switch to manifest-level rather than job-level.
SETA doesn't care and just runs the high value jobs, no matter what, as the builds are always run anyway. We can definitely do the same on autoland, and for try we can choose a specific platform.

We could train a model to choose on which platforms to run a given manifest.

We could use past failures data, just as we do for choosing manifests.

The main problem is that we don't run tests on all platforms normally. So, if we have a push where we run a test only on a given platform, how do we know if it was a platform-specific failure or if it just happened to run only on that platform? Idea from @jmaher: "could we weight regression data?  when we run all the tests there is a weight of 1, when we have partial tests it is <1 ?".

Another option is to train the model on the historical data normally, then select platforms based on risk levels. If Linux risk is high, we select only Linux. If Linux risk is low and Windows risk is high, we select Windows.

Yet another option: a model which selects (config, manifest), then we check for redundancies and e.g. if we have (config1, manifest) (config2, manifest) always failing together, then we choose only one of the two.

issue.title: Support analyzing pushes at the (platform/configuration, manifest) level

repository.name: mozci
repository.description: A library for inspecting push and task results in Mozilla's CI

issue.body:
We currently consider two types of runnables: label and group.
For the group runnable, we bundle together runs of the same group on multiple configurations.

In order to make bugbug select the platform/config too (https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/issues/1117), we should create another type of runnable which takes into account both the platform/config AND the group.

NOTE: if a push runs a group on a given platform but doesn't run the same group on another platform, we can't be sure if it would have failed on that other platform too or not. This makes checking if a regression is a prior regression a bit less precise.
E.g., say group A fails on Windows in push 1 and fails on Linux in push 2. At the group level, it would be considered as a prior regression. At the (platform/config, group) level, it would not be considered as a prior regression.
